linkTarget.anchoringText: In a bottom water drive, the aquifer is present below the entire reservoir and water influx moves vertically upward into the oil zone. In an edge water drive, the aquifer is located on the flanks of the reservoir and the water moves upward along the reservoir dip, different aquifer geometry will give different energy and give different end result in terms the value of maximal recovery factor based on log data and depth structure analysis, for example the edge water aquifer in asri basin sand 34-X (Fig.1).

image-wrap.label: Figure 1
image-wrap.caption: Edge water aquifer example in asri basin sand 34-X

formatted-caption.caption-text: Edge water aquifer example in asri basin sand 34-X

linkTarget.anchoringText: The 34-X divided into 2 area east and west, start produce in 1990 in east area, the initial pressure was 1,600 psi (Fig.2), and west area start produce in 2000 with initial pressure at 1,000 Psi, after 27 years of production the 34-X reservoir pressure decrease to 800 Psi (Fig.3) quite stable for long period of time. From material balance method, the most robust and easy to understood is pressure history matching method, the pressure match method employs an iterative procedure that uses the values of original oil-in-place, original gas-inplace, and W to calculate the reservoir pressure versus time.

image-wrap.label: Figure 2
image-wrap.caption: 34-X East Pressure history from first production at 1990

formatted-caption.caption-text: 34-X East Pressure history from first production at 1990

linkTarget.anchoringText: The 34-X divided into 2 area east and west, start produce in 1990 in east area, the initial pressure was 1,600 psi (Fig.2), and west area start produce in 2000 with initial pressure at 1,000 Psi, after 27 years of production the 34-X reservoir pressure decrease to 800 Psi (Fig.3) quite stable for long period of time. From material balance method, the most robust and easy to understood is pressure history matching method, the pressure match method employs an iterative procedure that uses the values of original oil-in-place, original gas-inplace, and W to calculate the reservoir pressure versus time.

image-wrap.label: Figure 3
image-wrap.caption: 34-X West Pressure history from first production at 2000

linkTarget.anchoringText: From material balance method, the most robust and easy to understood is pressure history matching method, the pressure match method employs an iterative procedure that uses the values of original oil-in-place, original gas-inplace, and W to calculate the reservoir pressure versus time. The pressure match is then plotted against the real measured static reservoir pressures and compared between 34-X east (Fig.4) and 34-X west (Fig.5).

From material balance method, the most robust and easy to understood is pressure history matching method, the pressure match method employs an iterative procedure that uses the values of original oil-in-place, original gas-inplace, and W to calculate the reservoir pressure versus time. The pressure match is then plotted against the real measured static reservoir pressures and compared between 34-X east (Fig.4) and 34-X west (Fig.5).

The equation can be organized to show linear behaviour. if the water influx is neglected in calculating the terms the result will be non-linear behaviour on the plot. This can be a diagnostic to determine the presence of water drive. In practice, the scatter in the data may be great enough and the signature of water drive subtle enough that deviation from linear behaviour on the Havlena-Odeh plot may go unnoticed. The Havlena-Odeh plot for 34-X east (Fig.6) and west (Fig.7) showing linear match that indicates the presence of water influx, and the free gas terms was eliminated.

The equation can be organized to show linear behaviour. if the water influx is neglected in calculating the terms the result will be non-linear behaviour on the plot. This can be a diagnostic to determine the presence of water drive. In practice, the scatter in the data may be great enough and the signature of water drive subtle enough that deviation from linear behaviour on the Havlena-Odeh plot may go unnoticed. The Havlena-Odeh plot for 34-X east (Fig.6) and west (Fig.7) showing linear match that indicates the presence of water influx, and the free gas terms was eliminated.

The tracer data is very useful to confirm well connectivity and reservoir heterogenity, some reservoir model need to be updated in terms of permeability distribution (facies modeling), because breakthrough time from the tracer are way more long rather than estimation from the model. For example at IN field, breakthrough estimation from simulation are 372 days for well IN-X (Fig.8), in a reality tracer detected after 884 days (Fig.9).

The tracer data is very useful to confirm well connectivity and reservoir heterogenity, some reservoir model need to be updated in terms of permeability distribution (facies modeling), because breakthrough time from the tracer are way more long rather than estimation from the model. For example at IN field, breakthrough estimation from simulation are 372 days for well IN-X (Fig.8), in a reality tracer detected after 884 days (Fig.9).

One of the examples is NIT field at sand 30-X, to prove the strong water drive reservoir, the producing GOR remains fairly constant (Fig.10), reflecting the stable reservoir pressure that remains stable (Fig.11). However, if the aquifer is unable to maintain reservoir pressure, the producing GOR will rise accordingly. Oil rates remain high under strong water drive until water breaks through in the producing wells.

One of the examples is NIT field at sand 30-X, to prove the strong water drive reservoir, the producing GOR remains fairly constant (Fig.10), reflecting the stable reservoir pressure that remains stable (Fig.11). However, if the aquifer is unable to maintain reservoir pressure, the producing GOR will rise accordingly. Oil rates remain high under strong water drive until water breaks through in the producing wells.

However, if the aquifer is unable to maintain reservoir pressure, the producing GOR will rise accordingly. Oil rates remain high under strong water drive until water breaks through in the producing wells. Water production usually occurs early in the field life of down structure wells, and the water-oil ratio (WOR) continues to increase until water production gets excessive with time as the oil-water contact moves upward (Fig.12).

image-wrap.label: Figure 12
image-wrap.caption: 30-X Water cut history, showing well flow until water production gets excesive

formatted-caption.caption-text: 30-X Water cut history, showing well flow until water production gets excesive

linkTarget.anchoringText: Compartmentalised reservoir in Windri area divided into 5 sweep pattern (Fig.13) to make analysis more detail and accurate. Each of compartment have different characteristic, and it help us to control and make better understanding about water injection condition and pattern in Windri area. Group 1 located in most western of Windri area, in consist of WF-03 producer and WF-04 injector wells and both of them can be pairing one injector and one producer. Group 2 structurally higher than group 1, it consist of WN-02, WF-01 producer and WF-02, WF-06 injector.

image-wrap.label: Figure 13
image-wrap.caption: 5 sweep pattern of compartmentalised reservoir in Windri area divided

formatted-caption.caption-text: 5 sweep pattern of compartmentalised reservoir in Windri area divided

linkTarget.anchoringText: After evaluating the productivity of the well, upzinging the ESP is an opportunity to increase the production fluid, therefore the ESP was change from Q10 with capacity range 600 – 1250 bfpd to Q20 with capacity range 1150 – 2050 bfpd. With both combination of increasing fluid rate and decreasing water cut, WW D-29 become successful pilot project. The water cut was decrease from 98% to 83% in the lowest water cut, then sustain in 92%WC (Fig.14), while oil increase fom 20 BOPD to 300 BOPD (Fig.15).

After evaluating the productivity of the well, upzinging the ESP is an opportunity to increase the production fluid, therefore the ESP was change from Q10 with capacity range 600 – 1250 bfpd to Q20 with capacity range 1150 – 2050 bfpd. With both combination of increasing fluid rate and decreasing water cut, WW D-29 become successful pilot project. The water cut was decrease from 98% to 83% in the lowest water cut, then sustain in 92%WC (Fig.14), while oil increase fom 20 BOPD to 300 BOPD (Fig.15).

image-wrap.label: Figure 15
image-wrap.caption: Production Well Test of WD-D29 Before and After Treatment

formatted-caption.caption-text: Production Well Test of WD-D29 Before and After Treatment

linkTarget.anchoringText: Several lab analysis were conducted to identify fluid corrosive content. Water analysis had been performed to see the character fluids in each well. Based on lab Analysis all water samples have scale forming instead of Corrosive (Fig.16). Gas analysis also concluded that there is no indication of corrosive behavior. Therefore, the solution is to do quality control for tubing specification and also improve the makeup tubing connection procedure.

image-wrap.label: Figure 16
image-wrap.caption: Water lab analysis, water sample has typical of scale forming instead of Corrosive

formatted-caption.caption-text: Water lab analysis, water sample has typical of scale forming instead of Corrosive
